text:
SOVEREIGNTY

God the Creator

(I)The order of creation in Genesis 1 

The Genesis 1 account gave the prelude that in the beginning, God created the heaven and the earth. At that point, the earth was without form and void, and darkness was upon the face of the deep. and the spirit of God was moving over the face of the waters. The creation of the world took God six days while he rested on the seventh day. The order is as follows: 

First day: Light was created and was separated from the darkness to form day and night. 

Second day: The heaven or the firmament was created. 

Third day: Land, sea and vegetations were created. 

Fourth day: The heavenly bodies or the luminaries (sun, moon and stars). 

Fifth day: Sea animals and birds. 

Sixth day: Land animals and man were created.

In the creation of man, special attention was giving to him When God said, “let us make man in our image and likeness; and let them have dominion over the fish of the sea, and over the birds of the air, and over the cattle, and over all the earth, and over every creeping thing that creeps upon the earth” (Gen. 1:26). 

God created them male and female with the blessing, “Be fruitful and multiply, and fill the earth and subdue it...” (v.28). 

Finally, having completed his work of creation and seeing that they were all good, God rested on the seventh day. He also blessed the day and hallowed it because on it he rested from all his work which he had done on creation. 

 

Example

What did God create on the fourth day?

A. The two great lights

B. The firmament C. Sea creatures

D. Water under the heavens

Option A

Reference: Genesis 1: 16 – 19

[16] And God made the two great lights, the greater light to rule the day, and the lesser light to rule the night; he made the stars also. 

[17] And God set them in the firmament of the heavens to give light upon the earth, 

[18] to rule over the day and over the night, and to separate the light from the darkness. And God saw that it was good. 

[19] And there was evening and there was morning, a fourth day.

 

Example

What was God’s purpose in creating man? 

A. To be master of all creation.

B. To help Him look after the garden.

C. To name the things He created.

D. To multiply and fill the earth.

Reference: Gen. 1: 26

[26] Then God said, "Let us make man in our image, after our likeness; and let them have dominion over the fish of the sea, and over the birds of the air, and over the cattle, and over all the earth, and over every creeping thing that creeps upon the earth."

 

The order of creation in Genesis 2 

The creation account in Genesis 2 centered on the creation of man which unlike in Genesis 1 where man was created out of nothing, Genesis 2 records that God created man out of the dust. [n the creation of man in Genesis 2, the Lord God formed man of dust from the ground, and breathed into his nostrils the breath of life and upon that man became a living being. Thereafter God planted a garden in Eden, in the east where he put the man he created. God made so many good trees that are good for food to grow and in the midst of the garden was the tree of life and the of the knowledge of good and evil. There was a river that flowed out of Eden to water the garden and there it divided and became four rivers. 

These are Pishon, Gihon, Tigris and Euphrates. Pishon flows around the whole land of Havilah; Gihon flows around the whole land of Cush; while Tigris flows east of Assyria. God placed man in the garden to till and keep it. 

He also commanded him to eat every tree of the garden but to stay away from the tree of the knowledge of good and evil warning that any time he eats of it he (man) will die. God then saw that it was not good that the man should be alone; he therefore decided to make a helpmate for him. 

Out of the ground the Lord made all the beast of the field and the birds of the air, these he brought to the man to see what he will call them. The man gave name to all cattle, birds and to every beast of the field, but no helpmate was found suitable for the man. 

As a result, God caused a deep sleep to fall upon the man and while he was asleep, God took one of the man’s ribs and enclosed it with flesh. He built the rib into a woman and brought her to the man who exclaimed, “This at last is bones and ‘flesh of my flesh; she shall be called woman, because she was taken Out of man” (Gen. 2; 23), This explains why a man should leave his father and his mother and Cleaves to his wife, and they become one flesh. 

At that point the man and the woman were both naked, and were not ashamed. 

The river that flowed out from Eden to water he garden divided into four rivers as follows:

 

Example

A. Euphrates, Tigris, Pishon and Havilah

B. Pishon, Cuhon, Havilah and Gihon

C. Havilah, Tigris, Gishon and Euphrates

D. Gihon, Pishon, Euphrates and Tigris

D

Gihon, Pishon, Euphrates and Tigris

Gen 2:14 And the name of the third river is Tigris, which flows east of Assyria. And the fourth river is the Euphrates.

 

The Account in Psalm 19: 1-6. 

The account in Psalm 19 is an allude to the creative work of God, his glory and a continuation of his power. In verse I, the heavens affirm the glory of God and the firmament proclaims the work of his hands. By implication, the heavenly hosts are attesting to the supremacy of God. 

From day to day, and night to night, the power and glory of God are manifested though these are not expressed in concrete words or speeches, yet their voice goes out through all the earth and their words to the end of the world. 

In them God set a tent for the sun, which comes forth like a bridegroom leaving his chamber, and like a strong man, runs its course with joy. 

Its rising is from the end of the heavens, and its circuit to the end of them; and there is nothing hid from its heat. 

 

THE SOVEREIGNTY OF GOD OVER HIS CREATION (Isaiah 45: 9-12) 

Prophet Isaiah likens the nature of God to an earthen vessel and the potter. The relationship is such that exists between a master, who has absolute control and the servant who is a subject to the master and has no power of its own. Isaiah therefore maintained that the clay as a subject cannot challenge its maker or the potter. 

He said, “Woe to him who strives with his Maker, an earthen vessel with the potter.” He went further to insist that the clay does not question the one who fashions it and woes anyone who says to the father, “What are you begetting? or to a woman, with what are you in travail?.” These are impossibilities and clear expression of the masters’ superiority over their subjects. 

In verses 11 and 12, the sovereign nature of God is affirmed as follows: 

“Will you question me about my children, or command me concerning the work of my hands? made the earth, and created man upon it; it was my hands that stretched out the heavens, and I commanded all their host.” 

 

Example

According to Prophet Isaiah, the creative ability of God is likened to that of a 

A. shepherd and his sheep

B. potter and his earthen vessel

C. ruler and his followers

D. master and his servant

Option B

Reference: Isaiah 64 : 8

[8] Yet, O LORD, thou art our Father; we are the clay, and thou art our potter;we are all the work of thy hand.

 

The Sovereignty of God over Individual Lives (Daniel 4: 4-37) 

In the book of Daniel, King Nebuchadnezzar is king over one of the powerful empire that has ever existed, the Babylon Empire. He was arrogant, confident, and it appeared that he was in absolute control of everything within the Empire and that he was sovereign over his own life and kingdom. 

However, in the fourth Chapter of Daniel he had a dream. Which disturbed him greatly that he summoned his magicians, the enchanters, the Chaldeans, the astrologers and sorcerers to interpret to him what the dream meant, but they could not help him. 

At last Daniel who was named Belteshazzar was called and asked to interpret the dream after the king had narrated the dream to him. Not being comfortable with the dream prophet Daniel was alarmed and said, “My lord, may the dream be for those who hate you and its interpretation for your enemies! 

The tree you saw, which grew and became strong, so that its top reached to heaven, and it was visible to the end of the whole earth; whose leaves were fair and its fruit abundant, and in which was food for all; under which beasts of the field found shade, and in whose branches the birds of the air dwelt - it's you, O king, who have grown and become strong” (4: 20-22). 

The interpretation of the dream suggested that the king has become power drunk and sees himself as a sovereign being. As a result, prophet Daniel pointed out that he will be driven away from the people and made to live with the wild animals, where he will be made to eat grass like an oxen until he acknowledges that the Most High is sovereign and rules over the kingdoms of men. 

He however advised the king to accept his counsel by leaving his sins and practicing righteousness through showing mercy to the oppressed.

 

Fulfillment of the Dream and the King’s Confession

At the end of twelve months, while the king was walking on the roof of the royal palace of Babylon, he said, “ls not this great Babylon, which I have built with my mighty power as a royal residence and for the glory of my majesty?” 

While the words were still in his mouth, there fell a voice from heaven, “O king Nebuchadnezzar, to you it is spoken: The kingdom has departed from you, and you shall be driven from among men, and your dwelling shall be with the beasts of the field; and you shall be made to eat grass like an oxen; and seven times shall pass over you, until you have learned that the Most High rules the kingdom of men and gives it to whom he will” (Daniel 4: 31-32). 

Immediately the king was driven from among men and he ate grass like an ox, and his body was drenched with the dew of heaven till his hair grew as long as eagles’ feathers and his nails were like birds’ claws. 

At last when the king regained his reasoning, he acknowledged the Sovereignty of God and his everlasting dominion. Having realized this, he blessed, praised and honoured God who lives for ever and whose kingdom endures from generation to generation. His confession (Daniel 4:28-37) is that of a man humbled before the source of absolute power and authority. 

 

Example

Daniel became distinguished above all the other presidents and satraps because he

A. was more educated than them

B. had a close relationship with the king

C. had an excellent spirit

D. was a Jew from Judah
